item.title: The case of Elgizouli v Secretary of State for the Home Department [2020] UKSC 10 involves issues related to data protection, the death penalty, and mutual legal assistance in criminal law.
item.description:
Lorna Woods, Professor of Internet Law, University of Essex Introduction The Elgizouli case marks the first UK Supreme Court ruling on the Data Protection Act 2018 (DPA). The key takeaway is that simply mostly complying with the Act’s requirements isn’t enough to legalize data transfers to other countries. This judgment centers around Part Three of the DPA, which puts the Law Enforcement Directive into action and emphasizes procedural safeguards. However, the court’s methodology might have broader consequences for how UK courts interpret the DPA and the GDPR, particularly regarding the protection of individual rights outlined in the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR)...
